column5: A longitudinal assessment of the academic correlates of early peer acceptance and rejection.
column10:
O'Neil, Robin

Welsh, Mara

Parke, Ross D

Wang, Shirley

Strand, Christine
column13: O'Neil, Robin: U California, Dept of Psychology, Riverside, CA, US
column14: Journal of Clinical Child Psychology. Vol.26(3), Sep 1997, pp. 290-303.
column17: Journal of Clinical Child and Adolescent Psychology
column22: Examines the extent to which academic achievement and work habits of first and second graders are predicted by classroom social status over the kindergarten, first-, and second-grade period. 345 children (163 boys and 182 girls) from a southern California community comprised the sample. The ethnic distribution of the sample was approximately 45% Caucasian, 42% Latino, 9% African American, and 5% Asian or other ethnicity. Findings suggest that peer rejection assessed as early as kindergarten and social rejection that is stable across 2 years (kindergarten-first grade or first-second grade) are associated with deficits in first-grade work habits and second-grade academic achievement and work habits. In contrast, stable social acceptance appears to buffer children from early academic difficulty. The pattern of findings remain significant after controlling for initial kindergarten academic competence. The implications for clinical and educational intervention programs are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: "Voices from the bridge" - Kickapoo Indian students and science education: A worldview comparison.
column10: Allen, Nancy Jane
column13: Allen, Nancy Jane: U Texas at Austin, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(10-A), Apr 1996, pp. 3898.
column22: The purpose of this study was to compare the world view of students of the Traditional Kickapoo Tribe, the most culturally conservative Native American group in the United States, with the world view encountered in the science classroom. The qualitative study investigated world view expressed in science instruction by conducting periodic observations in two science classrooms over a nine-month period, Semi-structured interviews were conducted with teachers (n = 2) who taught fifth and sixth grade science. Field notes and audio recordings provided data. Teachers were asked to review and comment on all analyzed data. Mainstream texts (n = 2) and texts written by and for Native Americans (n = 3) were examined for examples of expressed or implied world view. To define student world view, 28 Native American students in grades 5-9 were engaged in science activities at the reservation and interviewed singularly and in groups. Adult Native Americans were interviewed and asked to reflect on the educational and cultural norms of the students. Adult Native Americans were asked to review and comment on all analyzed data. Matrices and diagrams compared the worldview expressions obtained from teachers, texts, and students. A narrative described and gave examples of worldview expressions from each source of data. The variable-oriented analysis revealed strong differences in epistemology, preferred methods of teaching and learning, values, temporal/spatial orientation, and perspective of the place of humans in the natural world. Strong differences between teachers and students were also observed in prior knowledge, cultural rules for behavior and language patterns. It is hoped that this study will contribute to an understanding of the cultural basis of world view and the ways in which world view interacts with science instruction. The suggestions given for helping Native American students achieve in the science classroom may be applicable to students of other ethnicity and be helpf (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Comparative conflict resolution patterns among parent-teen dyads of four ethnic groups in Hawaii.
column10: Hartz, Diane T
column13: Hartz, Diane T.: Veterans Affairs Medical Ctr, Psychiatry Service, San Francisco, CA, US
column14: Child Abuse & Neglect. Vol.19(6), Jun 1995, pp. 681-689.
column22: Examined the self-reported behavior of 96 high school students (Grades 11 and 12) and the behavior of their parents in the resolution of conflicts during the previous year, using the Conflict Tactics Scales. Parent-teen dyadic aggression levels for Americans of European, Japanese, Polynesian, and Filipino ancestry were compared in a series of orthogonal contrasts. Ss with Polynesian American parents reported significantly higher parent aggression levels than did Ss with parents of other ethnicity. Parent aggression was the best predictor of teen aggression toward parents. Ss reciprocated with counteraggression toward European American parents more often than toward parents of other ethnicity. Aggression by 1 parent was highly correlated with aggression by the other parent. Aggression by either parent was more highly correlated with teen aggression toward the mother, than with teen aggression toward the father. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Configural coding, expertise, and the right hemisphere advantage for face recognition.
column10: Rhodes, Gillian
column13: Rhodes, Gillian: U Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand
column14: Brain and Cognition. Vol.22(1), May 1993, pp. 19-41.
column22: Two experiments investigated whether the orientation-specific right hemisphere advantage (RHA) for face recognition (FR) depends on lateralized configural coding mechanisms, and whether the use of such mechanisms requires expertise. In Exp 1, 32 Chinese residents of Singapore and 32 Caucasian residents of New Zealand were presented photographs of Chinese and Caucasian faces. Ss showed expertise-related use of configural coding, but no orientation-specific RHA advantage. In Exp 2, 64 Caucasian residents of New Zealand were shown photographs bilaterally, unilaterally, or chimerically. Ss with high hemispheric arousal asymmetry showed an orientation-specific RHA advantage, but no expertise-related use of configural coding. Low arousal asymmetry Ss showed the opposite pattern. Results suggest that different kinds of configural coding may underlie ethnicity-related expertise effects and laterality effects in FR. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
